claim: Traditional CT exams consist of the acquisition of sets of two-dimensional images, i.e., slices, that correspond to an amount of tissue, acquired consecutively over one of the three standard anatomic orientation planes: axial, coronal or sagittal (Fig. 1b-d).
title: Fig. 1.
caption: Explanation on the location and components of a CT exam: a) Depiction of the standard anatomical acquisition planes, b-d) CT slices in axial, coronal, and sagittal planes, e) A stack of CT axial slices that compose one CT exam, f) A 3D reconstruction of a liver obtained from its delineation on each axial slice of a CT exam

claim: Usually, a set of axial CT slices, each corresponding typically to an axial width of 1.5-10 cm, represents consecutive areas of the human abdominal cavity (Fig. 1e).
title: Fig. 1.
caption: Explanation on the location and components of a CT exam: a) Depiction of the standard anatomical acquisition planes, b-d) CT slices in axial, coronal, and sagittal planes, e) A stack of CT axial slices that compose one CT exam, f) A 3D reconstruction of a liver obtained from its delineation on each axial slice of a CT exam

claim: Any structure of interest can be delineated in each slice and finally stacked to build its three-dimensional (3D) model representation, as exemplified in Fig. 1f.
title: Fig. 1.
caption: Explanation on the location and components of a CT exam: a) Depiction of the standard anatomical acquisition planes, b-d) CT slices in axial, coronal, and sagittal planes, e) A stack of CT axial slices that compose one CT exam, f) A 3D reconstruction of a liver obtained from its delineation on each axial slice of a CT exam

claim: Figure 2 presents the resulting co-occurrence map.
title: Fig. 2.
caption: Network of co-occurring keywords generated from abstract and keyword text information from the found publications related to the semantic segmentation of liver structures in CT images published between 2019 and 2023

claim: The top co-cited relationships between publications can be observed in Fig. 3, where each node represents an article, the links between the authors represent co-citations, with the articles displayed in ascending date from left to right, and ascending cite count from bottom to top.
title: Fig. 3.
caption: Network of co-citation patterns for publications related to the semantic segmentation of liver structures in CT images published between 2019 and 2023

claim: Figure 4a depicts the proportion between the articles published in conference proceedings and journals.
title: Fig. 4.
caption: Publications published between 2019 and 2023 found in terms of (a) medium of publication (conference proceedings vs. journal article), (b) liver structure segmented (liver/tumor vs. vasculature), (c) semantic segmentation method used (“Traditional” method vs. Neuronal Network method) and (c) CNN architecture used

claim: In Fig. 4b, it is possible to observe the time evolution of the reviewed research regarding the articles found per year, grouped by the typology of the analysed structure.
title: Fig. 4.
caption: Publications published between 2019 and 2023 found in terms of (a) medium of publication (conference proceedings vs. journal article), (b) liver structure segmented (liver/tumor vs. vasculature), (c) semantic segmentation method used (“Traditional” method vs. Neuronal Network method) and (c) CNN architecture used

claim: Thus, in Fig. 4c, it is possible to observe the time evolution of the reviewed research in terms of “traditional” versus CNN-based methods.
title: Fig. 4.
caption: Publications published between 2019 and 2023 found in terms of (a) medium of publication (conference proceedings vs. journal article), (b) liver structure segmented (liver/tumor vs. vasculature), (c) semantic segmentation method used (“Traditional” method vs. Neuronal Network method) and (c) CNN architecture used

claim: In Fig. 4d, it is possible to observe the time evolution of the reviewed research regarding CNN architecture typology trends.
title: Fig. 4.
caption: Publications published between 2019 and 2023 found in terms of (a) medium of publication (conference proceedings vs. journal article), (b) liver structure segmented (liver/tumor vs. vasculature), (c) semantic segmentation method used (“Traditional” method vs. Neuronal Network method) and (c) CNN architecture used
